title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 5 units and/or does not explain that the 5th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($75) is greater than the marginal cost ($69); the firm will not produce the 6th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($82) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($75).

The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 5 units and explains that the 5th unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($75) is greater than the marginal cost ($69); the firm will not produce the 6th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($82) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($75).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the number of firms in the industry will increase and/or does not explain that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.
The response states that the number of firms in the industry will increase and explains that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the market price will decrease and/or does not explain that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.
The response states that the market price will decrease and explains that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand for televisions will decrease and/or does not explain that the positive cross-price elasticity of demand for televisions with respect to the price of Good K means that the goods are substitutes; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good K will lead to a decrease in the demand for televisions.

The response states that that the demand for televisions will decrease and explains that the positive cross-price elasticity of demand for televisions with respect to the price of Good K means that the goods are substitutes; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good K will lead to a decrease in the demand for televisions.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good K will stay the same in the short run and explains that property taxes are a fixed cost and a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that deadweight loss will increase and explains that a price floor above the equilibrium price is binding and the quantity exchanged in the market will be limited by the quantity demanded, which is less than the equilibrium quantity, thus decreasing total economic surplus.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good K will stay the same in the short run and explains that property taxes are a fixed cost and a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that deadweight loss will increase and explains that a price floor above the equilibrium price is binding and the quantity exchanged in the market will be limited by the quantity demanded, which is less than the equilibrium quantity, thus decreasing total economic surplus.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good K will stay the same in the short run and explains that property taxes are a fixed cost and a change in fixed cost does not affect the marginal cost.

· States that deadweight loss will increase and explains that a price floor above the equilibrium price is binding and the quantity exchanged in the market will be limited by the quantity demanded, which is less than the equilibrium quantity, thus decreasing total economic surplus.
